title: I still do  not believe you should be able to lose more LP than you gain
body: It makes it really hard to climb when you win 5 games and then lose 1 and bye bye lp. this isnt the case for me this season but last season they placed me in silver 4 and I gained 5 lp for a win and lost 20 for a loss not fair in my opinion.

replies.body: its based on your mmr.  if your matchmaking rating is lower than your rank then you are going to lose more points for loss than you gain on a win.  they are trying to make your rank the same as your mmr.
Yeah, I understand that, it just makes climbing impossible though.

> [{quoted}](name=Its Spongebob,realm=NA,application-id=cIfEodbz,discussion-id=vfM72uWh,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2015-03-21T06:06:38.389+0000)
>
> Yeah, I understand that, it just makes climbing impossible though.

It's SUPPOSED to make climbing difficult. If you are higher than you belong, it should be hard to climb.

The system wants you to prove that you belong where you are first and you do that by winning more than you lose and over time it'll gradually equalize and eventually spike up.

Not necessarily. MMR gains/losses are stable - you gain the same amount from a win as you lose from a loss.

So as long as you're winning more than you're losing, your MMR will increase. As your MMR increases, your LP gain/loss will stabilize. Should you increase your MMR *enough*, you'll start to see yourself gaining more LP than you're losing.
This is flawed. My d5 friend won 7 games in a row for 5-7 lp each, lost one and he lost 33 lp. It is ridiculously hard to climb once you get behind, and it is very very frustrating.

Well... yes. It is hard to climb once you get behind. But it's also hard to get significantly behind.

Consider: Your friend is *placed* in d5, but his MMR isn't at a d5 level. With a differential that high (win 5, lose 30), it's pretty significantly lower. With an MMR significantly below is ranking, it really *shouldn't* be easy for him to climb. After all, the goal is to keep the rank in tune with the hidden MMR.

If the system were more precise, your friend wouldn't be d5 at all - as it stands, it's simply trying to correct for a perceived mis-placement. Once it's corrected (either his rank drops to roughly where his MMR is, or his MMR raises to roughly where he's ranked), that LP gain/loss will stabilize.

It's not a perfect system, by any means, but it *is* effective.

Adding to that logic, it prevents winning streaks to take you too far ahead. Once you hit opponents with a much higher mmr than you and you lose, the system lowers your LP a bit so you can handle opponents again. Rinse, wash, repeat until you meet those opponents, with their mmr, and the odds are much more fair.

It *is* frustrating, but it makes sense.
yeah it takes forever to change your mmr.  it can be very frustrating

I agree. It's just not feasible and it keeps a lot of people (imo) out of ranked. Sure, I COULD play 300 games and even out my MMR so that it's "accurate" but I don't have that kind of time, patience, or League self-esteem to keep pressing the lever for an  unrewarding system. There needs to be a better way to identify where you belong in ranked.
